reviewText: Enjoyed this movie greatly. Tremendous story and factual history. Movies like this are seldom seen on the big screen today. If I could see more of this type of movies in the theater I would spend more time there instead of attending a theater only once in every five years.

reviewText: A good color film of the period seen thru Polish eyes. It gives a good insight into Polish history as well as that of the little known Teutonic Order, that originally did its crusading in the Holy Land. Its good to remember that from its lands the Duchy of Prussia was created.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Welcome to the Wild Wild East. This film accurately covers historical events, with great acting and relatively good fight scenes.  There is a great judicial combat scene.  In my opinion it's on the scale of one of the classic 1950's sword and sandals films like Ben Hur.  Because it was made in Communist Poland, it doesn't have the sort of puritan hangups that a Hollywood film from this era would have.  There is nudity and pretty harsh violence.Ok, the best "Medieval" themed films I've seen so far:Alexander Nevsky 1938Yojimbo 1961The Vikings with Kirk Douglas 1958The last valley (Directed by James Clavel) 1970Flesh and Blood with Rutger Hauer 1985If you go beyond the Medieval era I'd addThe duelists 1977Rob Roy 1995And this one.  This one is better than all the others except Yojimbo, but Yojimbo is set in Japan.  And it's the 19th Century but it's essentially the same as the Middle Ages.The other Polish Henryck Seinkowitz derived films based in the 17th Century are also very good, but a bit beyond the Medieval era.It's true what the other reviewers said about the subtitles, they go fast and get particularly hard to read during a section in the middle of the movie.  It would be really nice if someone restored this film and put in better subtitles.  But I still gave it 5 stars because it's such an excellent movie.  If you liked Lord of the Rings or Gladiator or Bravehart, give this one a chance, and have a glimpse into something a bit more like real Medieval Europe.
summary: The best medieval themed movie I've ever seen

reviewText: "Order of Teutonic Knights" was released in 1960 to international acclaim, and it remains a landmark film for Polish cinema. I'm sure that, when it first came out, it was quite a spectacular experience at the local theatre. Clocking in at just under three hours, it tells the tale of the rising conflict between Polish nobility in the Middle Ages and the very powerful multi-national order of titular knights who may be devout Christians, but are also ruthless in their determination to expand their power throughout Europe.There are some excellent performances in the film, and a number of memorable scenes. It has a very authentic "look", quite a contrast to some of Hollywood's medieval epics. Special kudos to the prolonged final battle scene--there were no computer-generated effects in those days--you really are looking at thousands of extras in this spectacular finale. This must have been a very expensive movie for the Polish film industry.Unfortunately there are some technical problems with the DVD which prevented me from giving "Knights" a higher rating. The dialogue is naturally in the original Polish with English subtitles--subtitles which far too often seem to be out of synch with the person who is speaking. The widescreen, colour image is not as crisp as it should be. There also appears to have been some "cropping"--for example, there is a scene early in the film where our young heroine is singing a song, and most of her head is "cut off". Unfortunately there are numerous other examples throughout the disc where heads, sometimes whole characters, seem to be missing from the scene. I also suspect that the film might not be the original, uncut version--there seem to be "jumps" in the storyline that cause the viewer to scratch his/her head a little !Bottom line--it would seem that we have a very fine film here that has not been presented on DVD with the technical quality that it deserves. Then again, the problem may originate with the source material--older films sadly do not always remain in pristine condition. So--recommended with caution.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Krzyzacy (Knights of the Teutonic Order) is a historical epic based on the book by Henryk Sienkiewicz.  The story is a fictionalized account of the days leading up to the decisive Polish-Lithuanian and Teutonic battle on July 15, 1410.  The Battle of Grunwald (or Tannenberg) began the decline of the Teutonic Order and is remembered and celebrated by its victors to this day.  The word "Krzyzacy" in Polish is referring to the large cross the Teutonic Knights were known for wearing on their tunic, in a way calling them cross wearers.  But these men of the cross also carried swords; their swords may have been used against pagans but Catholic Poles as well.Running nearly three hours in length, Krzyzacy shows us the political intrigue that leads up to the famous battle.  In a way, there is a lot of tit for tat between the Poles and the Teutonic Order.  In the early part of the story, a Polish noblewoman is killed by the Teutonic Knights and her husband goes to avenger her.  This leads to his daughter being taken hostage by the Order, which leads to further retaliation.  After several skirmished and duels, the battle is set to happen.  If you can, I would recommend watching Krzyzacy on a big screen to take in the massive final battle.Unquestionably, Krzyzacy is a classic and ranks among the best-known Polish cinema.  As Krzyzacy was made in 1960, not all the effects are realistic as they would be if made today.  Although it would be great to see a remake of Krzyzacy, it still will remain a classic that brings history to life.
summary: Krzyzacy is a classic and ranks among the best-known Polish cinema
Title: N/A

reviewText: KNIGHTS OF THE TEUTONIC ORDER (1960) Directed by Alexander Ford. Basedon the novel by Henryk Sienkiewicz.Starring many acrors and actresses with last names like Staniszewskaand Modrynska. Not to mention Jasiukiewicz and Bialoszynski.A Polish film from the Communist period set in the early 1400s tellingof a group of noble and heroic Poles on the border between Poland andPrussia aka Germany who are harassed and persecuted by a group ofKnights belonging to the Teutonic Order. As their fictional melodramaunfolds, behind the scenes war looms as the Order itself plots aninvasion of Eastern Europe leading to the famous Battle of Grunwald onJuly 15, 1410.A blockbuster in Poland when released and the country's submission tothe Academy Awards that year, this is, in actuality, a rather typicalPolish as well as European film from that period. Clunky. Poorlyedited. Badly scripted. Indifferently acted. Dripping with and sorendered lifeless by its leftist/communist propaganda. In many respectsthe thing is very similar to the Italian peplum films that were alsobegining to be made at the time and with all the same flaws.The Teutonic Knights are.....not surprisingly coded as being the Naziseven shrieking "Heil" at one point. But as this is a communist film,all of Western Europe is shown to be allied with them. And the film'santi-Christian and anti-Catholic in specific hatred is seething.Obviously intended to be the Polish version of ALEXANDER NEVSKY the 30sCommunist Russia film about the 1242 invasion of Russia by theTeutonic Knights, this film is also very similar to the recent RidleyScott film KINGDOM OF HEAVEN. In the Scott film, heroic Atheists andMuslims must unite to destroy those dirty Christians and Jews. In thisfilm, the message is more racially tinged though in a way designed tobenifit the Communist Party in that all Slavs must united to destroythose dirty Christians and non-Slavic Western Europeans. The film hasa couple of token "good" non-slavs. Literally two. But the viewercannot help but come away with the proper indoctrination.It is interesting how the Left just keep making the same films overand over again. Liberals should enjoy this though they will probablyhave difficulty with the lack of cgi.The film's fictional and historical plots never quite mesh. The noblePoles and wicked Teutons do their stuff for about 90 minutes of thethree hour film and then suddenly the historical material kicks in andthe viewer is introduced to a new set of characters while the fictionalones recede into the back ground and their basic plots are not evenresolved. Two minor support characters--one of which this viewerbarely remembered suddenly have a duel while the main Polish hero seemsto disapear from the picture. I should think Sienkiewicz's novel isbetter than what is on display here.Ford is no Eisenstein and the big battle of Grunwald at the end reallyisunimpressive and dull. There are a lot of guys clanking and bonginginto each other but there is no suspense, no excitement, no flow andthe battle is poorly delineated. It is very close to the Poles wonbecause they won.On the plus side. The film does capture the look and feel of Medievallife in Eastern Europe. The sets, castles and costumes are impressiveand there are many moments where the film is what it could have been.In spite of the seething hatred for Christianity, the film does areasonable job of showing how religion was a factor in everyone's livesand a major part of the culture. And the film IS covering a period ofhistory that has been untouched by Western film------surprising sinceone would think the chance to conflate National Socialism withChristianity would seem to be irrestible to modern filmmakers. In anycase, this viewer was unaware that there even WAS a famous Battle ofGrunwald until he saw this.....so the film achieved that.The film is not bad. It is not good. Moderately interesting, it isjust sort of there.
Title: N/A
